text: why are Nigerians having to queue up for
hours and hours to fill up their cars
with fuel well the reason is there is a
shortage and the fuel importers say that
the government owes them about a billion
dollars in arrears and the government
doesn't have the money at the moment to
pay them and each day that the fuel
crisis continues Nigerians are getting
more and more frustrated so there's your
Kanye pew for like hours maybe six hours
seven hours at the end of the or they
still go empty you still don't get those
four things out seeing maybe if I wait
for another two us if if nothing comes
up for what we just go home I have just
about a quarter left in my tank well why
on earth does Nigeria have a problem
importing fuel when this is after all
the biggest producer of crude oil on the
entire African continent well the answer
is simple the refineries in this country
simply don't work they're dilapidated
and they haven't been fixed for many
many years why not well because if they
were fix that might end an enormous
racket you see in Nigeria people get
fuel at a subsidized price and the
government pays the importers the
difference between the International
price of fuel and the low price that
people pay here at the pumps but then
what the importers do is they pretend
they're importing a lot more fuel than
they actually are
and they pocket the difference it is an
enormous scam that cost Nigeria billions
of dollars every year Nigeria has had
many fuel shortages before but this
one's different because we've just had
an election and the current government's
been voted out and many analysts feel
that the fuel importers are trying to
squeeze whatever they can out of the
current government before it hands over
this is special because this is the end
of its 60-year scam this is La Soria the
last party the Last Supper and the
benefits of any last camp will be
unbelievable because because that money
will be used for social programs for
education for
for infrastructure and of course it's
not just filling up the cars that's a
problem here because Nigeria's
electricity sector is in such a mess
people have to provide their own
electricity through generators and they
need fuel to do that so people are
desperate for this fuel crisis to end
